Re #23: Scott, I have the latest XCode, but I'm not able to build universal binaries of SWT on PowerPC.
I always have to use my macIntel for that.
I will post the error messages here...

Here is the output of building the SWT dll on PowerPC (the same builds fine on Intel).

build_carbon_lib:
        [exec] rm -f *.jnilib *.o
        [exec] cc -arch i386 -arch ppc -c -DSWT_VERSION=3218   -DCARBON -I /System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework/Headers swt.c
        [exec] cc -arch i386 -arch ppc -c -DSWT_VERSION=3218   -DCARBON -I /System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework/Headers callback.c
        [exec] cc -o libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib -arch i386 -arch ppc -bundle -framework JavaVM -framework Carbon  swt.o callback.o
        [exec] /usr/bin/ld: for architecture i386
        [exec] /usr/bin/ld: warning /System/Library/Frameworks/Carbon.framework/Carbon cputype (18, architecture ppc) does not match cputype (7) for specified -arch flag: i386 (file not loaded)
        [exec] /usr/bin/ld: warning fat file: /usr/lib/gcc/i686-apple-darwin8/4.0.1/../../../libSystem.dylib does not contain an architecture that matches the specified -arch flag: i386 (file ignored)
        [exec] /usr/bin/ld: warning /System/Library/Frameworks/Foundation.framework/Versions/C/Foundation cputype (18, architecture ppc) does not match cputype (7) for specified -arch flag: i386 (file not loaded)
        [exec] /usr/bin/ld: warning fat file: /usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib does not contain an architecture that matches the specified -arch flag: i386 (file ignored)
        [exec] /usr/bin/ld: Undefined symbols:
        [exec] _memset
        [exec] collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
        [exec] lipo: can't open input file: /var/tmp//ccG8oD9i.out (No such file or directory)
        [exec] make: *** [libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib] Error 1
        [exec] Result: 2

Google to the rescue...
I searched for "Universal Binaries Makefile" and found this link:
http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Porting/Conceptual/PortingUnix/compiling/chapter_4_section_3.html

   CFLAGS="-isysroot /Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.4u.sdk -arch ppc -arch i386"
instead of
  CFLAGS="-arch ppc -arch i386"

With this the errors disappeared and the Unix "file" command lists the jnilibs now as:

libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib:        Mach-O fat file with 2 architectures
libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib (for architecture ppc):       Mach-O bundle ppc
libswt-carbon-3218.jnilib (for architecture i386):      Mach-O bundle i386

I haven't tried them on MacIntel yet but they looks promising...

We have released temporary changes that will build universal binaries for the SWT libraries and for the eclipse launcher. For now, the SWT libraries are still in the "org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx.ppc" fragment even though they do not match the architure type.

So you should be able to run the next integration build out of the box.

The bug stays open until we decide what is the shape of our fragments. The options are:

1 fragment:
org.eclipses.swt.carbon.macosx.universal
     with libraries that are about double of the size

2 fragments:
org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx.ppc
org.eclipse.swt.carbon.macosx.x86

3 fragments:
all of the above

My personal opinion is that the 'universal' option is the best as it most closely matches how the platform thinks about binaries and makes it more likely that other native tools for eclipse follow this model.  Further, it would be nice to use a single eclipse install on either system type.

(In reply to comment #46)
> 1 fragment:
> org.eclipses.swt.carbon.macosx.universal
>      with libraries that are about double of the size

For what it's worth, the VM on an Intel machine returns 'ppc' as os.arch, so you won't be able to select on that. Building the SWT with both architectures in one binary is going to be the best option.

On the iMac Core Duo it returns i386 for both 1.5 and 1.4.2.  What machine and VM are you using that returns an incorrect answer?

(In reply to comment #48)
> For what it's worth, the VM on an Intel machine returns 'ppc' as os.arch, so
> you won't be able to select on that. Building the SWT with both architectures
> in one binary is going to be the best option.
This is news to me -- thanks for pointing it out! A colleague of mine said that we were returning 'ppc', so I took him at his word. I need to follow up on that!

Re comment #46:
I think a universal binary is the only viable option since processor architecture should be transparent for Mac users (if Eclipse is installed on shared volume, it should work for all clients).

BTW, the size size increase of the (uncompressed) libraries is < 500k and the size increase of the (compressed) swt jar file is about 100k.
If someone needs smaller libraries, there are enough tools to strip off the unnecessary part.

I think the universal option would be the best, too.

Isn't it true, that eclipse wants to be as platform independent as possible?
The fragment concept was only introduced to resolve issues that could not be done well in a generic way.
So if we could merge two possible fragments (ppc & x86) into one (universal), this is a step into the right direction imho.

Re comment #64 and #65:  
I've verified that the universal binary of SWT 3139 in fact contains my workaround for bug #104902.
However, this workaround seems only work for Text fields which are created with the SWT.PASSWORD style bit, not by calling Text.setEchoChar. Since Eclipse only uses the former (and IMO more correct) approach, I never experienced the setEchoChar problem and did not provide a workaround for that problem.

So you can either
- pass SWT.PASSWORD on Text creation and stop calling Text.setEchoChar(...), or
- call Text.setEchoChar(...) and fill the character in both byte halfs of the 16bit character,
   i.e. setEchoChar((c << 8) + c)

I didn't verify the second approach myself but I think it should work.

The download is of SWT version 3.1.0 and the version with Eclipse 3.1.2 is 3.1.1 (lots of versions, there).  Is there a fixed version out there?

This is the released version of 3.1.2, if it helps.

In reply to Comment  #64 From Paul Furbacher  and
Comment  #70 From Chris Rose (Chris, BTW, next time it is better to *attach* long stack traces instead ;-) )
which were experiencing pb with the patch SWT 3139 for Eclispe 3.1.2 using attachment from  comment #45.

The patched SWT has a version number of 3.1.0. and the standard SWT is 3.1.2.
Therefore you are resolving to the old swt instead of the new one.
To get to work fine, exit eclipse, move the standard mac os swt jar (version 3.1.2) outside of your plugins dir, put the patched SWT there, and restart with an eclipse -clean.

Or alternatively, patch the manifest witha new version like 3.1.2.1(which I did but did not find appropriate to post here: send me an email if you want the patched version).

It works beautifully on a powerbook 12'' g4 and a macpookpro duo core 15'' with the exact same distro.

And while I am it: ignore my comment Comment  #69  on os.arch . The osgi.arch resolves to ppc on a macbook pro, soe everything is fine!


Thanks Andre!

Thanks for providing the universal .jnilib files.  However, there are two problems with the file java_swt in every version of the universal binaries attached to this bug:

1) it is not executable (not a big deal since you can chmod it yourself)
2) it is not compiled to be universal

I need to get a universal copy of the file java_swt so we can distribute our application to users with intel macs, any suggestions?

You don't need java_swt, and it should be removed from the SWT
distribution.  You just need to use the -XstartOnFirstThread
option to the JVM.
